title: How to Make Christmas Tree Pinecones

steps.headline: Find or buy some pinecones.
steps.description: You can buy bags of pinecones from a craft store, or you can find them outside near a pine tree. The pinecones can be any shape or size, but tall pinecones will look more like Christmas trees than short ones. How many pinecones you get depends on how many trees you want to make. You will need 1 pinecone for each tree that you will be making. Pinecones sold in stores are typically scented. Be aware of this if you have allergies.

steps.headline: Clean found pinecones using a water and vinegar solution.
steps.description: Fill a bucket with 1 gallon (3.8 L) of water and 1/2 cup (240 mL) of vinegar. Place any pinecones that you found outside into the water, and weigh them down with a plate or bowl, if needed. Let the pinecones soak for 1 hour, then pull them out. Rinse the pinecones with fresh water. This will help remove any dirt or insects. Skip this step if you are using store-bought pinecones. Pinecones close up when they get wet. Don’t worry, they will open up again!

steps.headline: Allow the pinecones to dry after washing them.
steps.description: Spread the pinecones out on a sheet of newspaper in a warm, dry environment, then let them dry for several hours. You can also bake them in the oven a at 250 °F (121 °C) for 1 hour and 30 minutes to help speed up the process. To prevent the pinecones from steaming in the oven, let them air dry for about 15 minutes first to remove any excess water.

steps.headline: Remove any debris caught between the petals of the pinecones.
steps.description: This includes things like seeds, pine needles, and other types of leaves. Most of these should have come out when you washed the pinecones, but some may still be caught inside it. Go over your pinecones, and pull out anything caught between the petals. You should still do this if you bought your pinecones from a store. Some of them come with pine needles caught inside.

steps.headline: Cover your workstation with newspaper or a plastic tablecloth.
steps.description: It would be a good idea to wear a crafting apron or put on an old shirt. If you will be using spray paint to color your pinecones, step outside or find a well-ventilated place to work in.

steps.headline: Paint the pinecones green with acrylic craft paint or spray paint.
steps.description: Paint the top and sides of the pinecones first. Wait for the paint dry, then paint the bottom. Let the pinecones dry completely before moving on. This should only take 15 to 20 minutes, depending on the brand of paint you used. Use a small, flat paintbrush to apply paint to the pinecones. Hold the pinecone by the tip as you paint it. Once the pinecone is dry, you can paint over the tip. Shake the can of spray paint first, than apply 2 light coats of spray paint using a sweeping motion. Let each coat dry before doing the next 1.

steps.headline: Paint the tips of the pinecone petals white if you want to add “snow.” You don’t have to do this, but it’s a great way to make it look like it snowed on your Christmas tree pinecones.
steps.description: You can do this with a small paintbrush and white acrylic craft paint. Once again, let the paint dry before moving on. If you want a dimensional look, you could use white puffy paint instead. Apply it straight from the bottle using the applicator tip.

steps.headline: Seal the paint with acrylic sealer if you want to make it last.
steps.description: A spray sealer will be easier to use, but you can use the brush-on kind as well. You can use a matte finish for a more natural look, or a glossy finish for a glazed look. Make sure that any paint you applied earlier is completely dry before you apply the sealer. Let the sealer dry before moving on. This step is not absolutely necessary, but it will help keep the paint from chipping off later.

steps.headline: Add some glitter to the tips of the pinecone petals if you want extra sparkle.
steps.description: Use a small paintbrush to add some white school glue or tacky glue to the tip of each pinecone petal. Sprinkle glitter over the glue. Green is a great color to use, because it will make the tree look more magical. If you painted snow onto the pinecone, try iridescent or silver glitter instead. Extra-fine glitter will look nicer, but you can use plain, chunky glitter too. If you want to keep the glitter from shedding, use a small paintbrush to apply clear, acrylic sealer in a glossy finish over the glittered parts.

steps.headline: Wrap a thin ribbon around the pinecone if you want a garland.
steps.description: A thin silver or gold ribbon will work great for this. You can also use a necklace chain or silver/gold yarn instead. Secure both ends of the garland to your “tree” with glue. Make Christmas lights by stringing some glass beads onto green embroidery thread, then wrapping it around the pinecone. Leave some space between each bead. You can use any type of glue you want, but a fast-drying glue, such as hot glue, would be the best.

steps.headline: Glue tiny pompoms to the tips of the pinecone’s petals for the ornaments.
steps.description:
You can use tacky glue or hot glue for this. Place a drop of glue where you want the pompoms to go, then press the pompoms into the glue. If you don’t want to use glue and pompoms, you can draw dots using puffy paint instead. Here are some more cute ideas for ornaments:
Beads or pearls
Bracelet charms
Sequins
Tiny buttons
Mini Christmas ornaments

steps.headline: Use a button or bead for the topper.
steps.description:
Glue a star-shaped button or bead to the top of the tree for the topper. A fast-drying glue, such as hot glue, will work the best, but you can use tacky glue as well. If you don’t have any star-shaped buttons or beads, here are some other ideas for you to try:
Use an angel- or bow-shaped button or bead. Cut a star shape out of glittery paper and use that instead. Use a glittery foam sticker shaped like an angel, bow, or star. Tie a thin ribbon to the tip of the tree in a bow.

steps.headline: Glue a wine cork trunk to the bottom if you want a realistic tree.
steps.description: You don't have to do this, but it can give your tree a nice touch. Simply coat the end of a wine cork with hot glue or tacky glue, and press it against the bottom of the pinecone. The wine cork will give the tree a rustic touch. If you want it to be more realistic, paint it brown using acrylic craft paint. Wine corks can make these trees difficult to stand. Consider tying string to the top of the tree and turning it into an ornament.

steps.headline: Glue the pinecone to a mini flower pot, if you want a fancy tree.
steps.description: Buy a small, terracotta flower pot from the craft store that is a little smaller than the base of your pinecone. Paint the outside of the flower pot a festive color, then let the paint dry. Coat the rim of the flower pot with glue, then set the pinecone on top. Great festive colors include: red, white, green, silver, and gold. Paint some stripes or polka dots to the flower pot after the first coat of paint dries to make it fancier.

tyn: Green acrylic craft paint or spray paint
White school glue or tacky glue (for glitter)
Mini pompoms, buttons, beads, sequins, etc.
Angel-, bow-, or star-shaped buttons or beads
text:
Cleaning the Pinecones Find or buy some pinecones. You can buy bags of pinecones from a craft store, or you can find them outside near a pine tree. The pinecones can be any shape or size, but tall pinecones will look more like Christmas trees than short ones. How many pinecones you get depends on how many trees you want to make. You will need 1 pinecone for each tree that you will be making. Pinecones sold in stores are typically scented. Be aware of this if you have allergies. Clean found pinecones using a water and vinegar solution. Fill a bucket with 1 gallon (3.8 L) of water and 1/2 cup (240 mL) of vinegar. Place any pinecones that you found outside into the water, and weigh them down with a plate or bowl, if needed. Let the pinecones soak for 1 hour, then pull them out. Rinse the pinecones with fresh water. This will help remove any dirt or insects. Skip this step if you are using store-bought pinecones. Pinecones close up when they get wet. Don’t worry, they will open up again! Allow the pinecones to dry after washing them. Spread the pinecones out on a sheet of newspaper in a warm, dry environment, then let them dry for several hours. You can also bake them in the oven a at 250 °F (121 °C) for 1 hour and 30 minutes to help speed up the process. To prevent the pinecones from steaming in the oven, let them air dry for about 15 minutes first to remove any excess water. Remove any debris caught between the petals of the pinecones. This includes things like seeds, pine needles, and other types of leaves. Most of these should have come out when you washed the pinecones, but some may still be caught inside it. Go over your pinecones, and pull out anything caught between the petals. You should still do this if you bought your pinecones from a store. Some of them come with pine needles caught inside. Painting the Pinecones Cover your workstation with newspaper or a plastic tablecloth. It would be a good idea to wear a crafting apron or put on an old shirt. If you will be using spray paint to color your pinecones, step outside or find a well-ventilated place to work in. Paint the pinecones green with acrylic craft paint or spray paint. Paint the top and sides of the pinecones first. Wait for the paint dry, then paint the bottom. Let the pinecones dry completely before moving on. This should only take 15 to 20 minutes, depending on the brand of paint you used. Use a small, flat paintbrush to apply paint to the pinecones. Hold the pinecone by the tip as you paint it. Once the pinecone is dry, you can paint over the tip. Shake the can of spray paint first, than apply 2 light coats of spray paint using a sweeping motion. Let each coat dry before doing the next 1. Paint the tips of the pinecone petals white if you want to add “snow.” You don’t have to do this, but it’s a great way to make it look like it snowed on your Christmas tree pinecones. You can do this with a small paintbrush and white acrylic craft paint. Once again, let the paint dry before moving on. If you want a dimensional look, you could use white puffy paint instead. Apply it straight from the bottle using the applicator tip. Seal the paint with acrylic sealer if you want to make it last. A spray sealer will be easier to use, but you can use the brush-on kind as well. You can use a matte finish for a more natural look, or a glossy finish for a glazed look. Make sure that any paint you applied earlier is completely dry before you apply the sealer. Let the sealer dry before moving on. This step is not absolutely necessary, but it will help keep the paint from chipping off later. Add some glitter to the tips of the pinecone petals if you want extra sparkle. Use a small paintbrush to add some white school glue or tacky glue to the tip of each pinecone petal. Sprinkle glitter over the glue. Green is a great color to use, because it will make the tree look more magical. If you painted snow onto the pinecone, try iridescent or silver glitter instead. Extra-fine glitter will look nicer, but you can use plain, chunky glitter too. If you want to keep the glitter from shedding, use a small paintbrush to apply clear, acrylic sealer in a glossy finish over the glittered parts. Decorating the Trees Wrap a thin ribbon around the pinecone if you want a garland. A thin silver or gold ribbon will work great for this. You can also use a necklace chain or silver/gold yarn instead. Secure both ends of the garland to your “tree” with glue. Make Christmas lights by stringing some glass beads onto green embroidery thread, then wrapping it around the pinecone. Leave some space between each bead. You can use any type of glue you want, but a fast-drying glue, such as hot glue, would be the best. Glue tiny pompoms to the tips of the pinecone’s petals for the ornaments. You can use tacky glue or hot glue for this. Place a drop of glue where you want the pompoms to go, then press the pompoms into the glue. If you don’t want to use glue and pompoms, you can draw dots using puffy paint instead. Here are some more cute ideas for ornaments:
Beads or pearls
Bracelet charms
Sequins
Tiny buttons
Mini Christmas ornaments Use a button or bead for the topper. Glue a star-shaped button or bead to the top of the tree for the topper. A fast-drying glue, such as hot glue, will work the best, but you can use tacky glue as well. If you don’t have any star-shaped buttons or beads, here are some other ideas for you to try:
Use an angel- or bow-shaped button or bead. Cut a star shape out of glittery paper and use that instead. Use a glittery foam sticker shaped like an angel, bow, or star. Tie a thin ribbon to the tip of the tree in a bow. Glue a wine cork trunk to the bottom if you want a realistic tree. You don't have to do this, but it can give your tree a nice touch. Simply coat the end of a wine cork with hot glue or tacky glue, and press it against the bottom of the pinecone. The wine cork will give the tree a rustic touch. If you want it to be more realistic, paint it brown using acrylic craft paint. Wine corks can make these trees difficult to stand. Consider tying string to the top of the tree and turning it into an ornament. Glue the pinecone to a mini flower pot, if you want a fancy tree. Buy a small, terracotta flower pot from the craft store that is a little smaller than the base of your pinecone. Paint the outside of the flower pot a festive color, then let the paint dry. Coat the rim of the flower pot with glue, then set the pinecone on top. Great festive colors include: red, white, green, silver, and gold. Paint some stripes or polka dots to the flower pot after the first coat of paint dries to make it fancier.
sentences: Cleaning the Pinecones Find or buy some pinecones.
You can buy bags of pinecones from a craft store, or you can find them outside near a pine tree.
The pinecones can be any shape or size, but tall pinecones will look more like Christmas trees than short ones.
How many pinecones you get depends on how many trees you want to make.
You will need 1 pinecone for each tree that you will be making.
Pinecones sold in stores are typically scented.
Be aware of this if you have allergies.
Clean found pinecones using a water and vinegar solution.
Fill a bucket with 1 gallon (3.8 L) of water and 1/2 cup (240 mL) of vinegar.
Place any pinecones that you found outside into the water, and weigh them down with a plate or bowl, if needed.
Let the pinecones soak for 1 hour, then pull them out.
Rinse the pinecones with fresh water.
This will help remove any dirt or insects.
Skip this step if you are using store-bought pinecones.
Pinecones close up when they get wet.
Don’t worry, they will open up again!
Allow the pinecones to dry after washing them.
Spread the pinecones out on a sheet of newspaper in a warm, dry environment, then let them dry for several hours.
You can also bake them in the oven a at 250 °F (121 °C) for 1 hour and 30 minutes to help speed up the process.
To prevent the pinecones from steaming in the oven, let them air dry for about 15 minutes first to remove any excess water.
Remove any debris caught between the petals of the pinecones.
This includes things like seeds, pine needles, and other types of leaves.
Most of these should have come out when you washed the pinecones, but some may still be caught inside it.
Go over your pinecones, and pull out anything caught between the petals.
You should still do this if you bought your pinecones from a store.
Some of them come with pine needles caught inside.
Painting the Pinecones Cover your workstation with newspaper or a plastic tablecloth.
It would be a good idea to wear a crafting apron or put on an old shirt.
If you will be using spray paint to color your pinecones, step outside or find a well-ventilated place to work in.
Paint the pinecones green with acrylic craft paint or spray paint.
Paint the top and sides of the pinecones first.
Wait for the paint dry, then paint the bottom.
Let the pinecones dry completely before moving on.
This should only take 15 to 20 minutes, depending on the brand of paint you used.
Use a small, flat paintbrush to apply paint to the pinecones.
Hold the pinecone by the tip as you paint it.
Once the pinecone is dry, you can paint over the tip.
Shake the can of spray paint first, than apply 2 light coats of spray paint using a sweeping motion.
Let each coat dry before doing the next 1.
Paint the tips of the pinecone petals white if you want to add “snow.” You don’t have to do this, but it’s a great way to make it look like it snowed on your Christmas tree pinecones.
You can do this with a small paintbrush and white acrylic craft paint.
Once again, let the paint dry before moving on.
If you want a dimensional look, you could use white puffy paint instead.
Apply it straight from the bottle using the applicator tip.
Seal the paint with acrylic sealer if you want to make it last.
A spray sealer will be easier to use, but you can use the brush-on kind as well.
You can use a matte finish for a more natural look, or a glossy finish for a glazed look.
Make sure that any paint you applied earlier is completely dry before you apply the sealer.
Let the sealer dry before moving on.
This step is not absolutely necessary, but it will help keep the paint from chipping off later.
Add some glitter to the tips of the pinecone petals if you want extra sparkle.
Use a small paintbrush to add some white school glue or tacky glue to the tip of each pinecone petal.
Sprinkle glitter over the glue.
Green is a great color to use, because it will make the tree look more magical.
If you painted snow onto the pinecone, try iridescent or silver glitter instead.
Extra-fine glitter will look nicer, but you can use plain, chunky glitter too.
If you want to keep the glitter from shedding, use a small paintbrush to apply clear, acrylic sealer in a glossy finish over the glittered parts.
Decorating the Trees Wrap a thin ribbon around the pinecone if you want a garland.
A thin silver or gold ribbon will work great for this.
You can also use a necklace chain or silver/gold yarn instead.
Secure both ends of the garland to your “tree” with glue.
Make Christmas lights by stringing some glass beads onto green embroidery thread, then wrapping it around the pinecone.
Leave some space between each bead.
You can use any type of glue you want, but a fast-drying glue, such as hot glue, would be the best.
Glue tiny pompoms to the tips of the pinecone’s petals for the ornaments.
You can use tacky glue or hot glue for this.
Place a drop of glue where you want the pompoms to go, then press the pompoms into the glue.
If you don’t want to use glue and pompoms, you can draw dots using puffy paint instead.

Here are some more cute ideas for ornaments:
Beads or pearls
Bracelet charms
Sequins
Tiny buttons
Mini Christmas ornaments Use a button or bead for the topper.
Glue a star-shaped button or bead to the top of the tree for the topper.
A fast-drying glue, such as hot glue, will work the best, but you can use tacky glue as well.

If you don’t have any star-shaped buttons or beads, here are some other ideas for you to try:
Use an angel- or bow-shaped button or bead.
Cut a star shape out of glittery paper and use that instead.
Use a glittery foam sticker shaped like an angel, bow, or star.
Tie a thin ribbon to the tip of the tree in a bow.
Glue a wine cork trunk to the bottom if you want a realistic tree.
You don't have to do this, but it can give your tree a nice touch.
Simply coat the end of a wine cork with hot glue or tacky glue, and press it against the bottom of the pinecone.
The wine cork will give the tree a rustic touch.
If you want it to be more realistic, paint it brown using acrylic craft paint.
Wine corks can make these trees difficult to stand.
Consider tying string to the top of the tree and turning it into an ornament.
Glue the pinecone to a mini flower pot, if you want a fancy tree.
Buy a small, terracotta flower pot from the craft store that is a little smaller than the base of your pinecone.
Paint the outside of the flower pot a festive color, then let the paint dry.
Coat the rim of the flower pot with glue, then set the pinecone on top.
Great festive colors include: red, white, green, silver, and gold.
Paint some stripes or polka dots to the flower pot after the first coat of paint dries to make it fancier.
